title: Complementary and Alternative Medicine (CAM)
description: Types of therapies used in complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) in cancer care, such as mind-body methods like meditation and yoga, or biologically-based like herbs and vitamins. Massage, reiki, acupuncture, and traditional medical systems are included. Also mentioned are talking to your doctor about CAM and the safety of CAM.
cleaned_text: Complementary and Alternative Medicine Complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) is the term for medical products and practices that are not part of [standard medical care](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000689630&version=Patient&language=en). People with cancer may use CAM to - help cope with the side effects of cancer treatments, such as nausea, pain, and fatigue - comfort themselves and ease the worries of cancer treatment and related stress - feel that they are doing something to help with their own care - try to treat or cure their cancer [Integrative medicine](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000689097&version=Patient&language=en) is an approach to medical care that combines conventional medicine with CAM practices that have shown through science to be safe and effective. This approach often stresses the patient's preferences, and it attempts to address the mental, physical, and spiritual aspects of health. [Conventional medicine](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000449752&version=Patient&language=en) is a system in which health professionals who hold an M.D. (medical doctor) or D.O. (doctor of osteopathy) degree treat symptoms and diseases using drugs, radiation, or surgery. It is also practiced by other health professionals, such as nurses, pharmacists, physician assistants, and therapists. It may also be called [allopathic medicine](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000454742&version=Patient&language=en), [biomedicine](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000454745&version=Patient&language=en), Western, mainstream, or [orthodox medicine](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000454746&version=Patient&language=en). Some conventional medical care practitioners are also practitioners of CAM. Standard medical care is treatment that is accepted by medical experts as a proper treatment for a certain type of disease and that is widely used by healthcare professionals. Also called [best practice](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000346526&version=Patient&language=en), [standard of care](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000346525&version=Patient&language=en), and [standard therapy](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000044930&version=Patient&language=en). [Complementary medicine](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000044951&version=Patient&language=en) is used along with standard medical treatment but is not considered by itself to be standard treatment. One example is using [acupuncture](https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/cam/patient/acupuncture-pdq) to help lessen some side effects of cancer treatment. Less research has been done for most types of complementary medicine. [Alternative medicine](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000044921&version=Patient&language=en) is used instead of standard medical treatment. One example is using a special diet to treat cancer instead of cancer drugs that are prescribed by an oncologist. Less research has been done for most types of alternative medicine. Types of Complementary and Alternative Medicine Scientists learn about CAM therapies every day, but there is still more to learn. This list is meant to be an introduction to what types of CAM are practiced, not an endorsement. Some of the therapies listed below still need more research to prove that they can be helpful. If you have cancer, you should discuss your thoughts about using CAM with your health care provider before using the therapies listed below. People may use the term "natural," "holistic," "home remedy," or "Eastern Medicine" to refer to CAM. However, experts often use five categories to describe it. These are listed below with examples for each. Mind-body therapies These combine mental focus, breathing, and body movements to help relax the body and mind. Some examples are [meditation](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000730354&version=Patient&language=en): focused breathing or repetition of words or phrases to quiet the mind and lessen stressful thoughts and feelings. [biofeedback](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000044647&version=Patient&language=en): using special machines, the patient learns how to control certain body functions that are normally out of one's awareness (such as [heart rate](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000748353&version=Patient&language=en)and [blood pressure](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000462668&version=Patient&language=en)). [hypnosis](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000044675&version=Patient&language=en): a trance-like state in which a person becomes more aware and focused on certain feelings, thoughts, images, sensations or behaviors. A person may feel more calm and open to suggestion in order to aid in healing. [yoga](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000532135&version=Patient&language=en): ancient system of practices used to balance the mind and body through stretches and poses, meditation, and controlled breathing [tai chi](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000467869&version=Patient&language=en): a form of gentle exercise and meditation that uses slow sets of body movements and controlled breathing [imagery](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000045719&version=Patient&language=en): focusing on positive images in the mind, such as imagining scenes, pictures, or experiences to help the body heal - creative outlets: interests such as art, music, or dance Biologically based practices This type of CAM uses things found in nature. Some examples are [vitamin](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000044744&version=Patient&language=en)s: [nutrients](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000044697&version=Patient&language=en)the body needs in small amounts to function and stay healthy [dietary supplement](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000373932&version=Patient&language=en)s: products added to the diet that may contain ingredients such as vitamins, [minerals](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000045787&version=Patient&language=en), and [herbs](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000463714&version=Patient&language=en), to name a few - botanicals: plants or parts of plants. One type is [cannabis](https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/cam/patient/cannabis-pdq). - herbs and spices such as [turmeric](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000463050&version=Patient&language=en)or cinnamon (See [Herbs at a Glance](https://www.nccih.nih.gov/health/herbsataglance)) - herbs and spices such as - special foods or diets Manipulative and body-based practices These are based on working with one or more parts of the body. Some examples are - massage therapy: a therapy where the soft tissues of the body are kneaded, rubbed, tapped, and stroked [chiropractic therapy](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000729990&version=Patient&language=en): a type of manipulation of the spine, joints, and skeletal system [reflexology](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000689093&version=Patient&language=en): a type of massage in which pressure is applied to specific points on the feet or hands, which are believed to match up with certain parts of the body Energy healing Energy healing is based on the belief that a vital energy flows through the body. The goal is to balance the energy flow in the patient. There's not enough evidence to support the existence of energy fields. However, there are no harmful effects in using these approaches. Some examples are - reiki: placing hands lightly on or just above the person with the goal of guiding energy to help a person's own healing response [therapeutic touch](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000661960&version=Patient&language=en): moving hands over energy fields of the body or gently touching a person's body Whole medical systems These are healing systems and beliefs that have evolved over time in different cultures and parts of the world. Some examples are [Ayurvedic medicine](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000688801&version=Patient&language=en): a system from India in which the goal is to cleanse the body and restore balance to the body, mind, and spirit. It uses diet, herbal medicines, exercise, meditation, breathing, physical therapy, and other methods. [Traditional Chinese medicine](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000449722&version=Patient&language=en): based on the belief that qi (the body's vital energy) flows along meridians (channels) in the body and keeps a person's spiritual, emotional, mental, and physical health in balance. It aims to restore the body's balance between two forces called [yin and yang](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000454787&version=Patient&language=en). [Acupuncture](https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/cam/patient/acupuncture-pdq)is a common practice in Chinese medicine that involves stimulating certain points on the body to promote health, or to lessen disease symptoms and treatment side effects. - - naturopathic medicine: a system that avoids drugs and surgery. It is based on the use of natural agents such as air, water, light, heat and massage to help the body heal itself. It may also use herbal products, nutrition, acupuncture, and aromatherapy. For details about specific CAM therapies, NCI provides evidence-based Physician Data Query (PDQ) information for many CAM therapies in versions for both the [patient](/about-cancer/treatment/cam/patient) and [health professional](/about-cancer/treatment/cam/hp). Also see the National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health's page, [Cancer and Complementary Health Approaches: What You Need to Know](https://www.nccih.nih.gov/health/cancer-and-complementary-health-approaches-what-you-need-to-know) for more details about CAM and some of the current research. The Safety of CAM Some CAM therapies have undergone careful evaluation and have been found to be generally safe and effective. These include acupuncture, yoga, and meditation to name a few. However, there are others that do not work, may be harmful, or could interact negatively with your medicines. Natural does not mean safe CAM therapies include a wide variety of botanicals and nutritional products, such as herbal and [dietary supplements](/about-cancer/treatment/cam/patient/dietary-interactions-pdq), and vitamins. These products do not have to be approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) before being sold to the public. Also, a prescription isn't needed to buy them. Therefore, it's up to you to decide what's best for you. Some tips to keep in mind are below. - Herbal supplements may be harmful when taken by themselves, with other substances, or in large doses. For example, some studies have shown that [kava kava](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000463715&version=Patient&language=en), an herb that has been used to help with stress and anxiety, may cause liver damage. And [St. John](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=CDR0000044957&version=Patient&language=en), which some people use for depression, may cause certain cancer drugs to not work as well as they should. - Tell your doctor if you're taking any dietary supplements, even vitamins, no matter how safe you think they are. This is very important. Even though there may be ads or claims that something has been used for years, they do not prove that it's safe or effective. This is even more true when combined with your medicines. - Talk with your doctor about what you should be eating. It's common for people with cancer to have questions about different foods to eat during treatment. Yet it's important to know there isn't just one food or special diet that has proved to control cancer. It's always important for you to have a healthy diet, but especially now. Do the best you can to have a well-rounded approach, eating a variety of foods that are good for you. For advice about eating during and after cancer treatment, see the NCI booklet, [Eating Hints](https://www.cancer.gov/publications/patient-education/eating-hints). Talk with your doctor before you use CAM Cancer patients who want to use CAM should talk with their doctor or nurse. This is an important step because things that seem safe could be harmful or even interfere with your cancer treatment. It's also a good idea to learn if the therapy you're thinking about has been proven to do what it claims to do. Examples of questions to ask are below. What types of CAM therapies might help me - reduce my stress and anxiety? - feel less tired? - deal with cancer symptoms and side effects, such as pain or nausea? - sleep better? Don't be afraid to ask questions. It's okay to feel hesitant when asking about using CAM. But doctors want to know what concerns you have so they can give you the best possible care. Let them know that you would like to use CAM methods and want their input. Clinical Trials to Test CAM Therapies NCI and the National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health (NCCIH) are currently sponsoring or cosponsoring clinical trials that test CAM treatments and therapies in people. Some study the effects of complementary approaches used in addition to conventional treatments, and some compare alternative therapies with conventional treatments. You can find [a list of all cancer CAM clinical trials here](https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/cam-procedures).
